insights.summary: The NeuroReach VR system is under development, focusing on rehabilitation tasks with multimodal feedback and adaptive difficulty, but faces technical hurdles and requires further validation for clinical readiness.
insights.text: The NeuroReach VR system is designed to aid stroke patient rehabilitation through immersive tasks like pouring and tracing, utilizing visual, auditory, and haptic feedback (c0001). A key feature is its adaptive controller, which adjusts task difficulty and feedback based on real-time performance metrics such as on-path, tilt window, and spill proxy (c0002). However, the system is still in development, encountering challenges like anchor drift and inconsistent haptic support, necessitating solutions like relocalization and filtering (c0003). The specific VR hardware and the exact scope of Work Package 2 remain unclear, and the system's readiness for clinical application is questioned due to these ongoing development aspects (c0001, c0004).

1
NeuroReach VR
Mixed Reality Project Proposal
Supervised by: Marwen Mokni, Christoph Bauer, Petar Lukovic
October 6, 2025
GROUP MEMBERS
Partha Sarathi
Purkayastha
Alexandre Elsig Raphael Fl¨uckiger Rakhmatillokhon
Khoshimov
I. DESCRIPTION OF THE PROJECT
Goal: To build NeuroReach VR – a proof-of-concept mixed-reality system that trains stroke reach and grasp using
an ARAT-aligned pouring task [1] and an MX Ink tracing task with visual, auditory and haptic feedback [6], to
improve selective muscle activation in the arms for stroke rehabilitation. [2].
Idea: Quest 3S with Shared Spatial Anchors pins virtual halos to a real cup and jug while MX Ink provides stylus
pose and pressure for tracing with haptic ticks via Unity SendHapticImpulse. We compute on path, time in tilt
window, spill proxy and smoothness with SPARC, and adapt difficulty to keep the user in a target corridor.
Rationale: The design draws on motor learning and control theory, emphasizing that stroke recovery combines
adaptation and skill learning to achieve specific task goals [5]. Guided by optimal feedback control, path corri-
dors, goal halos, and error-contingent cues support goal-directed corrections. Task-specific ADL movements with
validated kinematic metrics use SPARC for smoothness, while conservative auditory pacing maintains performance
consistency [3].
II. WORK PACKAGES AND TIMELINE
Hardware & Software: The system runs on Meta Quest 3S using Logitech MX Ink for precision input and haptic
feedback, with an optional Myo armband for EMG biofeedback. It is developed in Unity (C#) for Android, logs
data in CSV and JSON formats, and uses Python notebooks for quick analysis and visualization.
Work Package 1 : Data Anchors, Integration and Calibration (Weeks 1–2)
Members Responsible: R. Khoshimov, A. Elsig
Description: Set up Quest 3 passthrough and Spatial Anchors; integrate MX Ink input and haptics; implement
CSV logger. Outcomes: Unity project with anchors and passthrough; MX Ink tracing sample running with haptic
ticks; one tap calibration UI. Challenges: Anchor drift; noisy tilt estimation; inconsistent haptic support. Solutions:
Relocalize anchors at session start; low pass tilt and debounce events;. Alternatives: Use fiducials instead of anchors;
run tracing without haptics.

intuitiveness of the feedback mechanisms and the motivational aspect of the gamified environment, with potential

Demonstration plan: (i) Live on-headset demo with quick anchor calibration, where user performs two one minute
pouring blocks and two tracing blocks with real time halos, ticks and error bars (ii) Projected dashboard shows
on path, tilt window, spills proxy, RMS error and SPARC updated per trial to observe real-time adaptive difficulty
and fading feedback based on the user’s muscle activation. (iii) An offline video presentation showcasing the full
demonstration loop and summarized pilot metrics.
IV. *OPTIONAL MYO ARMBAND EXTENSION
Goal: EMG biofeedback for wrist extension to complement pouring and tracing [4]. Idea: Stream Myo sEMG into
Unity, compute %MVC, show twin bars with target bands, add haptic tick and buzz feedback. Rationale: Improves
engagement and selective activation. Outcome: Quick add-on with extra KPIs (time-in-target, ratio, co-contraction)
and demo toggle mode.

[1] Margit Alt Murphy, Carin Will´en, and Katharina Stibrant Sunnerhagen. Movement kinematics during a drinking task are associated with
the activity capacity level after stroke. Neurorehabilitation and Neural Repair, 26(9):1106–1115, 2012.
[2] Daniel Berger and Andrea d’Avella. Myoelectric control and virtual reality to enhance motor rehabilitation after stroke. Frontiers in
Bioengineering and Biotechnology, 12:1376000, 2024.
[3] H. Huang, S. L. Wolf, and J. He. Recent developments in biofeedback for neuromotor rehabilitation. Journal of NeuroEngineering and
Rehabilitation, 3(11), 2006.
[4] H. P. Lin et al. A usability study on mobile emg-guided wrist extension training in subacute stroke patients (myoguide). Journal of
NeuroEngineering and Rehabilitation, 21:39, 2024.
[5] Maike Maier, Bel´en R. Ballester, and Paul F. M. J. Verschure. Principles of neurorehabilitation after stroke based on motor learning and
brain plasticity mechanisms. Frontiers in Systems Neuroscience, 13:74, 2019.
[6] Styrmir Saevarsson, Vala Gudmundsdottir, and Arni Kristjansson. Kinematic analysis of spiral drawing and clock drawing as measures
of upper limb function after stroke. Neuropsychological Rehabilitation, 25(5):744–763, 2015.

Work Package 3 : Adaptive controller & logging (Weeks 6–8)
Members Responsible: A. Elsig, R. Fl¨uckiger
Description: Rule based adaptation of corridor, tilt window and tracing tunnel; feedback fading from knowledge of
performance to knowledge of results; Outcomes: Adaptive controller with hysteresis; 50 to 90 Hz logging with rolling
summaries. Challenges: Overreactive difficulty oscillation; metric drift across sessions. Solutions: Moving average
with gates and floors; buffered asynchronous writes and per trial files. Alternatives: Manual override switches;
lightweight local database if CSV grows; fixed difficulty presets.
Work Package 4 : Pilot study and analysis (Weeks 9–12)
Members Responsible: P. S. Purkayastha, R. Khoshimov
Description: Evaluate the system with a 5-10 participant pilot study; Test usability and performance using a baseline,
training, retention protocol to inform final refinements. Outcomes: A polished system with documentation; A formal
study protocol with a performance dataset; A completed usability and analysis report. Challenges: Participant
recruitment delays; Technical instability. Solutions: Recruit early; Conduct internal dry runs to fix bugs. Alternatives:
Use a smaller cohort; Simplify the protocol if technical issues arise.
III. OUTCOMES AND DEMONSTRATION
Expected outcomes: (i) A working proof-of-concept prototype that turns kinematics into adaptive multimodal
feedback during pouring and tracing (ii) A logging and analytics tool that summarizes on path, tilt window, spills
proxy and SPARC smoothness (iii) A small pilot indicating increased time in tilt window and reduced RMS path
error with improved SPARC, consistent with drinking task kinematics and smoothness literature [5].
Evaluation plans: (i) A preliminary usability study with physiotherapists, collecting qualitative feedback through a
think-aloud protocol and post-session questionnaires. (ii) Assess the system’s perceived effectiveness, ease of use,
and fit to ARAT aligned tasks, with specific focus on clarity of halos, ticks and result cards (iii) Focus on the
intuitiveness of the feedback mechanisms and the motivational aspect of the gamified environment, with potential
for clinical application.
Demonstration plan: (i) Live on-headset demo with quick anchor calibration, where user performs two one minute
pouring blocks and two tracing blocks with real time halos, ticks and error bars (ii) Projected dashboard shows
on path, tilt window, spills proxy, RMS error

insights.summary: The system's adaptive nature and feedback mechanisms are central to its rehabilitation goals, but the precise metrics and implementation details require clarification.
insights.text: The NeuroReach VR system aims to personalize stroke rehabilitation by dynamically adjusting task difficulty and fading feedback based on user performance (c0002). This adaptive control is crucial for tailoring the training experience, moving from knowledge of performance to knowledge of results (c0002). While the system incorporates various metrics like on-path and tilt window (c0002), the mention of SPARC metrics is not fully supported by the provided evidence (c0002). Furthermore, the evidence details the construction of specific tasks and their immediate outcomes, rather than a comprehensive demonstration of the adaptive controller's full capabilities and fading feedback implementation (c0002).

insights.summary: Technical challenges in VR implementation, such as anchor stability and haptic consistency, are being addressed through specific engineering solutions and alternative approaches.
insights.text: Developing an immersive VR rehabilitation system involves overcoming significant technical obstacles. Challenges like anchor drift and noisy tilt estimation are being tackled through methods such as relocalizing anchors at the start of sessions and applying low-pass filters to tilt data (c0003). Inconsistent haptic support is also a concern, with alternative solutions like running tracing without haptics being considered (c0003). The adaptive controller itself requires robust design to manage difficulty oscillations and metric drift, employing techniques like moving averages and buffered writes (c0003). These ongoing efforts highlight the iterative nature of developing reliable VR rehabilitation tools.

Outcomes: Unity project with anchors and passthrough; MX Ink tracing sample running with haptic
ticks; one tap calibration UI. Challenges: Anchor drift; noisy tilt estimation; inconsistent haptic support. Solutions:
Relocalize anchors at session start; low pass tilt and debounce events;. Alternatives: Use fiducials instead of anchors;
run tracing without haptics.
Work Package 2 : VR Task and Multimodal Feedback (Weeks 3–5)
Members Responsible: P. S. Purkayastha, R. Fl¨uckiger
Description: Build Passthrough Pouring task; build MX Ink Tracing task; add neon halos and virtual liquid particles;
Outcomes: Playable pouring with on path, tilt window and spill proxy; tracing with tunnel and live error; UI to
configure thresholds and BPM; single screen results card. Challenges: Stable spill detection; tunnel width and tilt
window tuning. Solutions: One trial calibration; on device tooltips and ghost path. Alternatives: Use geometric spill
proxy; reduce tracing set to line and spiral.

actions.title: Clarify the specific VR hardware and its implications for anchor stability and haptic consistency.
actions.detail: The claim mentions a 'Quest 3S headset' (c0001), but the evidence does not specify the VR hardware being used. Given that anchor drift and inconsistent haptic support are identified challenges (c0003), understanding the exact hardware and its known limitations or capabilities in these areas is crucial for assessing the feasibility and robustness of the NeuroReach VR system. This clarification will inform potential mitigation strategies and the overall reliability of the system's immersive and interactive features.

actions.title: Hypothesize the clinical efficacy of adaptive difficulty and fading feedback based on user performance metrics.
actions.detail: The system's adaptive controller is designed to adjust task parameters and fade feedback based on user performance (c0002, c0004). However, the evidence focuses on the implementation details rather than the direct impact on rehabilitation outcomes. A hypothesis needs to be formed and tested regarding how specific adaptive strategies (e.g., the rate of difficulty increase, the transition from knowledge of performance to knowledge of results) correlate with improved reach and grasp movements in stroke patients. This will require defining specific performance benchmarks and measuring patient progress.

actions.title: Investigate the integration and distinct focus of Work Packages 2 and 3.
actions.detail: Challenge c0004 highlights an apparent overlap and lack of clarity regarding the distinct focus of Work Package 2 (Passthrough Pouring and MX Ink Tracing tasks) and Work Package 3 (adaptive controller and logging). The evidence suggests a demonstration plan integrates elements from both. Next steps should involve a detailed breakdown of the deliverables and objectives for each work package to ensure a clear development roadmap and to understand how the specific tasks in WP2 are intended to inform or be controlled by the adaptive mechanisms in WP3.

actions.title: Clarify the full suite of metrics used for adaptive control and their clinical relevance.
actions.detail: Challenge c0002 points out that while SPARC metrics are mentioned in a claim, the evidence only details on-path, tilt window, and spill proxy metrics. To fully understand the adaptive controller's capabilities and its potential for clinical application, it's essential to clarify if SPARC metrics are indeed being used and how they, along with the other mentioned metrics, are being translated into adjustments for difficulty and feedback fading. This clarification will help assess the comprehensiveness of the performance evaluation and the system's ability to provide meaningful rehabilitation insights.

actions.title: Explore alternative solutions for anchor drift and haptic inconsistency in a clinical setting.
actions.detail: Challenge c0003 identifies anchor drift and inconsistent haptic support as significant technical hurdles. While solutions like relocalizing anchors and low-pass filtering are being explored, the claim also mentions alternative solutions such as using fiducials instead of anchors or running tracing without haptics. Further investigation into the feasibility and trade-offs of these alternatives, particularly in a clinical environment where reliability and patient experience are paramount, is a critical next step. This will inform the most robust and clinically viable path forward.

challenges.claim_text: The NeuroReach VR system aims to train stroke patients in reach and grasp movements using an ARAT-aligned pouring task and an MX Ink tracing task. This system will provide visual, auditory, and haptic feedback to enhance selective muscle activation in the arms for stroke rehabilitation. The project utilizes a Quest 3S headset with Shared Spatial Anchors to create an immersive and interactive training environment. The intuitiveness of feedback mechanisms and the motivational aspect of the gamified environment are key features of the system, with potential for clinical application.
challenges.summary: The evidence suggests the system is still in development with significant challenges and potential alternatives, indicating it may not be ready for clinical application as claimed.
challenges.detail: The evidence snippets highlight several challenges in the development of the NeuroReach VR system, including 'anchor drift,' 'noisy tilt estimation,' and 'inconsistent haptic support' (E2). Furthermore, the proposed solutions involve workarounds like 'relocalizing anchors at session start' and 'low pass tilt and debounce events' (E2), suggesting the core technology is not yet robust. The project also considers alternatives such as 'using fiducials instead of anchors' or 'running tracing without haptics' (E2), which deviate from the claimed multimodal feedback system. The mention of a 'pilot study and analysis' with a small participant group (5-10) (E1) further indicates the system is in an early evaluation phase, not yet proven for clinical application.

Work Package 3 : Adaptive controller & logging (Weeks 6–8)
Members Responsible: A. Elsig, R. Fl¨uckiger
Description: Rule based adaptation of corridor, tilt window and tracing tunnel; feedback fading from knowledge of
performance to knowledge of results; Outcomes: Adaptive controller with hysteresis; 50 to 90 Hz logging with rolling
summaries. Challenges: Overreactive difficulty oscillation; metric drift across sessions. Solutions: Moving average
with gates and floors; buffered asynchronous writes and per trial files. Alternatives: Manual override switches;
lightweight local database if CSV grows; fixed difficulty presets.
Work Package 4 : Pilot study and analysis (Weeks 9–12)
Members Responsible: P. S. Purkayastha, R. Khoshimov
Description: Evaluate the system with a 5-10 participant pilot study; Test usability and performance using a baseline,
training, retention protocol to inform final refinements. Outcomes: A polished system with documentation; A formal
study protocol with a performance dataset; A completed usability and analysis report. Challenges: Participant
recruitment delays; Technical instability. Solutions: Recruit early; Conduct internal dry runs to fix bugs. Alternatives:
Use a smaller cohort; Simplify the protocol if technical issues arise.
III. OUTCOMES AND DEMONSTRATION
Expected outcomes: (i) A working proof-of-concept prototype that turns kinematics into adaptive multimodal
feedback during pouring and tracing (ii) A logging and analytics tool that summarizes on path, tilt window, spills
proxy and SPARC smoothness (iii) A small pilot indicating increased time in tilt window and reduced RMS path
error with improved SPARC, consistent with drinking task kinematics and smoothness literature [5].
Evaluation plans: (i) A preliminary usability study with physiotherapists, collecting qualitative feedback through a
think-aloud protocol and post-session questionnaires. (ii) Assess the system’s perceived effectiveness, ease of use,
and fit to ARAT aligned tasks, with specific focus on clarity of halos, ticks and result cards (iii) Focus on the
intuitiveness of the feedback mechanisms and the motivational aspect of the gamified environment, with potential
for clinical application.
Demonstration plan: (i) Live on-headset demo with quick anchor calibration, where user performs two one minute
pouring blocks and two tracing blocks with real time halos, ticks and error bars (ii) Projected dashboard shows
on path, tilt window, spills proxy, RMS error

challenges.claim_text: Work Package 2 focuses on building the Passthrough Pouring task and the MX Ink Tracing task, incorporating visual elements like neon halos and virtual liquid particles. This package also includes the integration of multimodal feedback, such as visual, auditory, and haptic cues. Work Package 3 is dedicated to developing an adaptive controller with hysteresis and implementing logging features with rolling summaries at high frequencies (50 to 90 Hz). The adaptive controller aims to manage feedback fading and adjust task parameters based on user performance.
challenges.summary: The claim describes Work Package 2 focusing on specific tasks and multimodal feedback, but the evidence details a demonstration plan that seems to integrate elements from both Work Package 2 and 3, making the distinct focus of WP2 unclear.
challenges.detail: The claim states Work Package 2 focuses on Passthrough Pouring and MX Ink Tracing with visual and multimodal feedback. However, the evidence (E1) outlines a demonstration plan that includes 'real time halos, ticks and error bars' (consistent with WP2's visual elements) but also mentions a 'Projected dashboard shows on path, tilt window, spills proxy, RMS error and SPARC updated per trial to observe real-time adaptive difficulty and fading feedback based on the user’s muscle activation.' This adaptive difficulty and fading feedback, along with muscle activation, are described as features of the adaptive controller in Work Package 3. The evidence does not clearly delineate which features belong to WP2 and which to WP3, or how they are integrated within the demonstration.

Demonstration plan: (i) Live on-headset demo with quick anchor calibration, where user performs two one minute
pouring blocks and two tracing blocks with real time halos, ticks and error bars (ii) Projected dashboard shows
on path, tilt window, spills proxy, RMS error and SPARC updated per trial to observe real-time adaptive difficulty
and fading feedback based on the user’s muscle activation. (iii) An offline video presentation showcasing the full
demonstration loop and summarized pilot metrics.
IV. *OPTIONAL MYO ARMBAND EXTENSION
Goal: EMG biofeedback for wrist extension to complement pouring and tracing [4]. Idea: Stream Myo sEMG into
Unity, compute %MVC, show twin bars with target bands, add haptic tick and buzz feedback. Rationale: Improves
engagement and selective activation. Outcome: Quick add-on with extra KPIs (time-in-target, ratio, co-contraction)
and demo toggle mode.
REFERENCES
[1] Margit Alt Murphy, Carin Will´en, and Katharina Stibrant Sunnerhagen. Movement kinematics during a drinking task are associated with
the activity capacity level after stroke. Neurorehabilitation and Neural Repair, 26(9):1106–1115, 2012.
[2] Daniel Berger and Andrea d’Avella. Myoelectric control and virtual reality to enhance motor rehabilitation after stroke. Frontiers in
Bioengineering and Biotechnology, 12:1376000, 2024.
[3] H. Huang, S. L. Wolf, and J. He. Recent developments in biofeedback for neuromotor rehabilitation. Journal of NeuroEngineering and
Rehabilitation, 3(11), 2006.
[4] H. P. Lin et al. A usability study on mobile emg-guided wrist extension training in subacute stroke patients (myoguide). Journal of
NeuroEngineering and Rehabilitation, 21:39, 2024.
[5] Maike Maier, Bel´en R. Ballester, and Paul F. M. J. Verschure. Principles of neurorehabilitation after stroke based on motor learning and
brain plasticity mechanisms. Frontiers in Systems Neuroscience, 13:74, 2019.
[6] Styrmir Saevarsson, Vala Gudmundsdottir, and Arni Kristjansson. Kinematic analysis of spiral drawing and clock drawing as measures
of upper limb function after stroke. Neuropsychological Rehabilitation, 25(5):744–763, 2015.

NeuroReach VR
Mixed Reality Project Proposal
Supervised by: Marwen Mokni, Christoph Bauer, Petar Lukovic
October 6, 2025
GROUP MEMBERS
Partha Sarathi
Purkayastha
Alexandre Elsig Raphael Fl¨uckiger Rakhmatillokhon
Khoshimov
I. DESCRIPTION OF THE PROJECT
Goal: To build NeuroReach VR – a proof-of-concept mixed-reality system that trains stroke reach and grasp using
an ARAT-aligned pouring task [1] and an MX Ink tracing task with visual, auditory and haptic feedback [6], to
improve selective muscle activation in the arms for stroke rehabilitation. [2].
Idea: Quest 3S with Shared Spatial Anchors pins virtual halos to a real cup and jug while MX Ink provides stylus
pose and pressure for tracing with haptic ticks via Unity SendHapticImpulse. We compute on path, time in tilt
window, spill proxy and smoothness with SPARC, and adapt difficulty to keep the user in a target corridor.
Rationale: The design draws on motor learning and control theory, emphasizing that stroke recovery combines
adaptation and skill learning to achieve specific task goals [5]. Guided by optimal feedback control, path corri-
dors, goal halos, and error-contingent cues support goal-directed corrections. Task-specific ADL movements with
validated kinematic metrics use SPARC for smoothness, while conservative auditory pacing maintains performance
consistency [3].
II. WORK PACKAGES AND TIMELINE
Hardware & Software: The system runs on Meta Quest 3S using Logitech MX Ink for precision input and haptic
feedback, with an optional Myo armband for EMG biofeedback. It is developed in Unity (C#) for Android, logs
data in CSV and JSON formats, and uses Python notebooks for quick analysis and visualization.
Work Package 1 : Data Anchors, Integration and Calibration (Weeks 1–2)
Members Responsible: R. Khoshimov, A. Elsig
Description: Set up Quest 3 passthrough and Spatial Anchors; integrate MX Ink input and haptics; implement
CSV logger. Outcomes: Unity project with anchors and passthrough; MX Ink tracing sample running with haptic
ticks; one tap calibration UI. Challenges: Anchor drift; noisy tilt estimation; inconsistent haptic support. Solutions:
Relocalize anchors at session start; low pass tilt and debounce events;. Alternatives: Use fiducials instead of anchors;
run tracing without haptics.
